across.text: Bat observed by queen, possibly, in tree
across.explanation: PUSSY WILLOW(i.e. “tree”). Solution is WILLOW (i.e. cricket “bat”) placed after or “by” PUSSY (i.e. “queen”, or adult female cat).

across.text: Family member’s move getting visitor finally into trouble
across.explanation: STEPBROTHER(i.e. “family member”). Solution is STEP (i.e. “move”) followed by R (i.e. “visitor finally”, i.e. the last letter of “visitor”) once placed “into” BOTHER (i.e. “trouble”), like so: STEP-B(R)OTHER.

across.text: Mad Finn began fiddling, swearing appallingly
across.explanation: EFFING AND BLINDING(i.e. “swearing appallingly”). “Mad” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of FINN BEGAN FIDDLING.

across.text: Piece of information corporation attorney provided first
across.explanation: DATUM(i.e. “piece of information”). Solution is TUM (i.e. “corporation” – setters love this archaic variant meaning of the word) with DA (i.e. “attorney”, specifically a District Attorney) “provided first”, like so: DA-TUM.

across.text: Harebrained son of spiteful disposition
across.explanation: SCATTY(i.e. “harebrained”). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “son”) followed by CATTY (i.e. “of spiteful disposition”).

across.text: Revolutionary figure recalled in register
across.explanation: LENINIST(i.e. “revolutionary”). Solution is NINE (a number or “figure”) reversed (indicated by “recalled”) and placed “in” LIST (i.e. “register”), like so: L(ENIN)IST.

across.text: Footwear found in coach
across.explanation: TRAINER. Solution satisfies “footwear” and “coach”.

across.text: Work with men broken by media tyrant
across.explanation: OPPRESSOR(i.e. “tyrant”). Solution is OP (i.e. “work”, short for “opus”) and OR (i.e. “men”, specifically the Other Ranks of the British Army) “broken by” PRESS (i.e. “media”), like so: OP-(PRESS)-OR.

across.text: Like some highly flavoured cake Liberal consumed with caution
across.explanation: GINGERLY(i.e. “with caution”). Solution is GINGERY (i.e. “like some highly flavoured cake”) wrapped around or “consuming” L (a recognised abbreviation of “Liberal”), like so: GINGER(L)Y.

across.text: Reportedly a female unit of heredity
across.explanation: GENE(i.e. “unit of heredity”). “Reportedly” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of JEAN (i.e. “female”, basically a woman’s name).

across.text: Severe pain encountered in French and African state
across.explanation: EGYPT(i.e. “African state”). Solution is GYP (i.e. “severe pain”) placed “in” ET (i.e. “French and”, i.e. the French for “and”), like so: E(GYP)T.

across.text: Crustacean current lawmaker found crossing Italian river?
across.explanation: ISOPOD(i.e. “crustacean”). Solution is I (a recognised abbreviation of an electrical “current” used in physics) followed by SOD (i.e. “lawmaker” – a reference to Sod’s Law) once wrapped around or “crossing” PO (i.e. “Italian river”), like so: I-SO(PO)D.

across.text: Varsity athlete with courage, a member of the constabulary
across.explanation: BLUEBOTTLE(i.e. “a member of the constabulary”). Solution is BLUE (i.e. “varsity athlete” – could be Oxford in dark blue or Cambridge in light blue) followed by BOTTLE (i.e. “courage”).

across.text: Unworldly woman seen around army corps area
across.explanation: ETHEREAL(i.e. “unworldly”). Solution is ETHEL (i.e. a “woman’s” name) wrapped “around” RE (i.e. “army corps”, specifically the Royal Engineers of the British Army) and A (a recognised abbreviation of “area”), like so: ETHE(RE-A)L.

across.text: Omnipresence of posh bishop I left over by American cape
across.explanation: UBIQUITOUSNESS(i.e. “omnipresence”). Solution is U (i.e. “posh” – U denotes the upper class, don’t you know, what-what-what, tallyho and so forth, old thing) followed by B (a recognised abbreviation of “bishop” used in chess), then I, then QUIT (i.e. “left”), then O (a recognised abbreviation of “over” used in cricket), then US (i.e. “American”) and NESS (i.e. “cape”, as in the geographic feature).

across.text: Terribly idle woman is not without depth
across.explanation: TWO-DIMENSIONAL(i.e. “without depth”). “Terribly” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of IDLE WOMAN IS NOT.

across.text: Malicious goddess ensnaring old doctor
across.explanation: VENOMOUS(i.e. “malicious”). Solution is VENUS (i.e. “goddess”) wrapped around or “ensnaring” O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) and MO (i.e. “doctor” or Medical Officer), like so: VEN(O-MO)US.

across.text: Generous, though suffering from cardiomegaly?
across.explanation: BIG-HEARTED. Solution satisfies “generous” and “suffering from cardiomegaly”.

across.text: Run into upholstered seat used by several in squat?
across.explanation: CROUCH(i.e. “squat”). Solution is R (a recognised abbreviation of “run”) placed “into” COUCH (i.e. “upholstered seat”), like so: C(R)OUCH.

across.text: Hard man repeatedly supplying meat acceptable to Muslims
across.explanation: HALAL(i.e. “meat acceptable to Muslims”). Solution is H (a recognised abbreviation of “hard” used in the grading of pencils) followed by AL and AL (i.e. “man[‘s name] repeatedly”).

across.text: Censor both sides of agreement secured by company
across.explanation: CATO(i.e. “censor” of Roman times). Solution is AT (i.e. “both sides of agreement”, i.e. the first and last letters of “agreement”) placed in or “secured by” CO (a recognised abbreviation of “company”), like so: C(AT)O.

across.text: European embassy, one of those we’re trying to cut?
across.explanation: EMISSION(i.e. “one of those we’re trying to cut” – timely given the recent COP26 summit). Solution is E (a recognised abbreviation of “European”) followed by MISSION (i.e. “embassy”).

across.text: Role in theatrical do for men only
across.explanation: STAG PARTY(i.e. “do for men only”). Solution is PART (i.e. “role”) placed “in” STAGY (i.e. “theatrical”), like so: STAG(PART)Y.

across.text: Exceed allotted time with respect to race
across.explanation: OVERRUN(i.e. “exceed allotted time”). Solution is OVER (i.e. “with respect to”) followed by RUN (i.e. “race”).

across.text: Pitiful way it gets knocked back in City area
across.explanation: PATHETIC(i.e. “pitiful”). Solution is PATH (i.e. “way”) followed by IT once it has been reversed (indicated by “knocked back”) and placed “in” EC (i.e. “City [of London] area”, a reference to its postcode), like so: PATH-E(TI)C.

across.text: Cross about start of feisty female’s gag?
across.explanation: MUFFLE(i.e. “gag”). Solution is MULE (i.e. “cross” between a horse and a donkey) wrapped “about” F (i.e. “start of feisty”, i.e. the first letter of “feisty”) and F (a recognised abbreviation of “female”), like so: MU(F-F)LE.

across.text: I visit the Hollywood area, having false notions
across.explanation: IDOLA(i.e. “having false notions” – over to Chambers: an idol can be “a false notion or other erroneous way of looking at things to which the mind is prone as classified by Bacon in Novum Organum”. Glad that’s cleared up, then). When written as I DO LA the solution also satisfies “I visit the Hollywood area”.(cough)made-to-fit(cough)

across.text: Injuries shown by Scottish poet with PhD, perhaps?
across.explanation: SECOND-DEGREE BURNS(i.e. “injuries”). Clue plays on a PhD being a SECOND DEGREE earned by postgraduates, and Robert BURNS being a “Scottish poet”.

across.text: Remedial treatment for cutie following censure
across.explanation: THERAPEUTIC(i.e. “remedial”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “treatment for”) of CUTIE placed after or “following” THE RAP (i.e. “censure”), like so: (THE-RAP)-EUTIC.

across.text: Uncommon process involving fluorine becoming less dense
across.explanation: RAREFACTION(i.e. of air “becoming less dense”). Solution is RARE (i.e. “uncommon”) and ACTION (i.e. “process”) wrapped around or “involving” F (chemical symbol of “fluorine”), like so: RARE-(F)-ACTION.

down.text: Silence poet’s representation of a prehistoric age
down.explanation: PLEISTOCENE(i.e. “prehistoric age”). “Representation” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of SILENCE POET.

down.text: Capital I invested in upholstered seat
down.explanation: SOFIA(i.e. “capital” city of Bulgaria). Solution is I placed or “invested in” SOFA (i.e. “upholstered seat”), like so: SOF(I)A.

down.text: Dread losing son before sharp double bend: you must cross that river!
down.explanation: YANGTZE(i.e. “river”). Solution is ANGST (i.e. “dread”) with the S removed (indicated by “losing son” – S being a recognised abbreviation of “son”) and followed by Z (i.e. “sharp double bend”, descriptive of the letter Z’s shape). These are then placed in or “crossed” by YE (i.e. ye olde “you”), like so: Y(ANGT-Z)E.

down.text: Terrible ruler’s current form of transport
down.explanation: IVAN(i.e. “terrible ruler”, i.e. Ivan the Terrible). Solution is I (a recognised abbreviation of an electrical “current”) followed by VAN (i.e. “form of transport”).

down.text: New maid’s role involving old woman’s retreat?
down.explanation: LADIES ROOM(i.e. “woman’s retreat”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “new”) of MAID’S ROLE wrapped around or “involving” O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”), like so: LADIESR(O)OM.

down.text: Western jazzman too biased at first over footwear
down.explanation: WELLINGTON BOOT(i.e. “footwear”). Solution is W (a recognised abbreviation of “western”) followed by Duke ELLINGTON (i.e. “jazzman”), then TOO and B (i.e. “biased at first”, i.e. the first letter of “biased”) once these latter two have been reversed (indicated by “over”), like so: W-ELLINGTON-(B-OOT).

down.text: Feeling transmitted by head of Irish hospital department
down.explanation: SENTIENT(i.e. “feeling”). Solution is SENT (i.e. “transmitted”) followed by I (i.e. “head of Irish”, i.e. the first letter of “Irish”) and ENT (i.e. “hospital department”, specifically Ear Nose and Throat).

down.text: Time to get upset about Conservative decree
down.explanation: EDICT(i.e. “decree”). Solution is TIDE (i.e. “time”, poetically) reversed (indicated by “to get upset” – this being a down clue) and wrapped “about” C (a recognised abbreviation of “Conservative”), like so: EDI(C)T.

down.text: Beautiful girl holding a gun? A thing of little significance
down.explanation: BAGATELLE(a trinket or “thing of little significance”). Solution is BELLE (i.e. “beautiful girl”) wrapped around or “holding” A GAT (i.e. “a gun”, short for Gatling), like so: B(A-GAT)ELLE.

down.text: Nightmare of French exam taken externally
down.explanation: ORDEAL(i.e. “nightmare”). Solution is DE (i.e. “of French”, i.e. the French for “of”) placed in or having “externally” ORAL (i.e. “exam”), like so: OR(DE)AL.

down.text: Very angry, like a boxer on a sweltering day?
down.explanation: HOT UNDER THE COLLAR(i.e. “very angry”). Clue plays on “boxers” being dogs, dogs often wear collars, you get the idea.

down.text: Hard-hearted note on inspector? Not so
down.explanation: REMORSELESS(i.e. “hard-hearted”). Solution is RE (i.e. “note”) followed by MORSE (i.e. “inspector” of Colin Dexter’s novels) and LESS (i.e. “not so” much).

down.text: Evaluate French art this writer’s exhibited in gallery
down.explanation: ESTIMATE(i.e. “evaluate”). Solution is ES (i.e. “French art” – we’ve seen this a couple of times now: “art” is being taken as a ye olde form of “are”; the French for “are” is ES) followed by I’M (i.e. “this writer’s” taken from the point of view of the setter, a contraction of I AM) once placed or “exhibited in” TATE (i.e. “gallery”), like so: ES-T(I’M)ATE.

down.text: Settle extortionate bill involving hooter?
down.explanation: PAY THROUGH THE NOSE(i.e. “settle extortionate bill”). Clue plays on “hooter” being an informal name for a NOSE.

down.text: Rich confection English girl left unfinished
down.explanation: ÉCLAIR(i.e. “rich confection”). Solution is E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”) followed by CLAIRE (i.e. a “girl’s” name) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “unfinished”), like so: E-CLAIR.

down.text: Thus otters originally plunged into river – truly
down.explanation: FORSOOTH(i.e. “truly”). Solution is SO (i.e. “thus”) and O (i.e. “otters originally”, i.e. the first letter of “otters”) both placed “into” FORTH (i.e. “river”), like so: FOR(SO-O)TH.

down.text: Name one’s used to cover extremities of these insects
down.explanation: TERMITES(i.e. “insects”). Solution is TERM (i.e. “name”) followed by I’S (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one’s”) once placed around or “covering” TE (i.e. “extremities of these”, i.e. the first and last letters of “these”), like so: TERM-I(TE)’S.

down.text: RAF officer “S”?
down.explanation: SQUADRON LEADER(i.e. “RAF officer”). Clue plays on S being the start letter or LEADER of the word SQUADRON.

down.text: Become excessively agitated about eliminating round
down.explanation: OVERHEAT(i.e. “become excessively agitated”). Solution is OVER (i.e. regarding or “about”) followed by HEAT (i.e. “eliminating round” in sports).

down.text: Evaluate merchandise ultimately carried in a couple of ships
down.explanation: ASSESS(i.e. “evaluate”). Solution is E (i.e. “merchandise ultimately”, i.e. the last letter of “merchandise”) placed or “carried in” A, SS and SS (i.e. “couple of ships”, SS is a recognised abbreviation of a steamship), like so: A-SS-(E)-SS.

down.text: Trader’s con cost a bit, unfortunately
down.explanation: TOBACCONIST(i.e. “trader”). “Unfortunately” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of CON COST A BIT.

down.text: Poor ass is lonely – nothing much happening now
down.explanation: SILLY SEASON(i.e. “nothing much happening now”. Chambers offers this: “a time of year, usually late summer, when newspapers print trivial matter for lack of more newsworthy material”). “Poor” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of ASS IS LONELY.

down.text: Greek characters hang about, arresting duke’s malicious vilifier
down.explanation: MUDSLINGER(i.e. “malicious vilifier”). Solution is MUS (i.e. “Greek characters” – mu is the twelfth letter of the Greek alphabet) and LINGER (i.e. “hang about”) all wrapped around or “arresting” D (a recognised abbreviation of “duke”), like so: MU(D)S-LINGER.

down.text: Recapture thoughts about skirts causing excitement at first
down.explanation: REMINISCE(i.e. “recapture thoughts”). Solution is RE (i.e. regarding or “about” – think email replies) followed by MINIS (i.e. “skirts”), then C and E (i.e. “causing excitement at first”, i.e. the first letters of “causing” and “excitement”).

down.text: Like works of poet and philosopher briefly taking pick-me-up
down.explanation: MILTONIC(i.e. “like works of poet”, specifically John Milton). Solution is John Stuart MILL (i.e. a “philosopher” who couldn’t handle his shandy, some might say) with its last letter removed (indicated by “briefly”) and the remainder followed by TONIC (i.e. “pick-me-up”), like so: MIL-TONIC.

down.text: Sound iron chest primarily containing lead
down.explanation: PLUMBIC(i.e. “containing lead”). Solution is PLUMB (i.e. “sound” – once more to Chambers: “to sound as by a plumb line”, whatever that means) followed by I and C (i.e. “iron chest primarily”, i.e. the first letters of “iron” and “chest”).

down.text: A jolly girl – and fleet
down.explanation: ARMADA(i.e. “fleet” of ships). Solution is A followed by RM (i.e. “jolly”, slang for a Royal Marine, it says here), then ADA (i.e. a “girl’s” name – names are clearly this setter’s calling card).

down.text: Feature of needlework originally produced in bed
down.explanation: PICOT(i.e. “feature of needlework”). Solution is P and I (i.e. “originally produced in”, i.e. the first letters of “produced” and “in”) followed by COT (i.e. “bed”).

down.text: Asian language principally spoken in remote island
down.explanation: FARSI(i.e. “Asian language”). Solution is S (i.e. “principally spoken”, i.e. the first letter of “spoken”) placed “in” FAR (i.e. “remote”) and I (a recognised abbreviation of “island”), like so: FAR-(S)-I.

down.text: Man once bound to take to the waves, we hear?
down.explanation: SERF(i.e. “man once bound”). “We hear” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of SURF (i.e. “to take to the waves”).
